title: implementing From<AsRef<LocalStruct>> for a foreign type
body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

I tried this code:

```rust
impl<T: AsRef<Header>> From<T> for [u8; 20] {
    fn from(header: T) -> [u8; 20] {
        let mut buf = [0u8; 20];
        unimplemented!();
    }
}
```
where `Header` is a local struct.

I expected to see this happen:
It should work in Rust 1.41+

Instead, this happened: 
```
type parameter `T` must be used as the type parameter for some local type (e.g., `MyStruct<T>`)

type parameter `T` must be used as the type parameter for some local type

note: implementing a foreign trait is only possible if at least one of the types for which it is implemented is local
note: only traits defined in the current crate can be implemented for a type parameter
```

**Expectation:**

`T: AsRef<Header>` should be considered a local type because it's trait specification is relying on a local type.
The alternative is having to use `.into()` for types that implement `Into<&Header>`

Unless I shouldn't use `AsRef` in the first place?

It also forces me to write
```rust
let buf: [u8; 20] = (&header).into();
```
instead of
```rust
let buf: [u8; 20] = header.into();
```
assuming a `From<&Header>` implementation.
